title: 111_hr3382
content: The "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" or the "HIRE Act of 2009" aims to address the economic losses in the home furnishing and building products market. It highlights the significant job losses in this sector and proposes deductions for purchases of personal use building products and home furnishings to stimulate the economy. The "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" proposes deductions for purchases of qualified building products and home furnishings for individuals to stimulate the economy. The maximum deduction is $2,000 for joint returns and $1,000 for other cases, with a doubling of the limitation for products meeting environmental standards. The proposed tax deduction for purchases of qualified building products and home furnishings is subject to an adjusted gross income limitation based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. Recognized environmental standards include LEED, Green Globes, and Energy Star, as well as other widely recognized national or industry standards with a positive life cycle analysis. The tax deduction for qualified building products and home furnishings is limited based on modified adjusted gross income. The applicable limitation is $300,000 for joint returns and $150,000 for other cases. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' excludes specific sections and is rounded to the nearest $10. The tax deduction for qualified building products and home furnishings is limited based on modified adjusted gross income. The deduction applies to products applied within 6 months of purchase in the taxpayer's principal residence, excluding certain items like home electronics, appliances, housewares, decorations, and depreciable property. The tax deduction for building products and home furnishings includes labor costs for onsite preparation, assembly, or installation. The deduction does not apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2011. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code to incorporate the deduction allowed by section 224. Amendments are made to the tax code by adding new items to the table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1. The tax code is amended to include a new section providing a credit for purchases of personal use building products and home furnishings, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. The tax code amendment allows individuals a 20% credit on the cost of qualified building products and home furnishings, capped at $500 for joint returns ($250 for others). The credit is subject to an adjusted gross income limitation and applies to products meeting environmental standards. The tax code amendment provides a 20% credit on qualified building products and home furnishings, with a cap of $500 for joint returns ($250 for others). The credit is subject to income limitations and applies to products meeting environmental standards. Labor costs for onsite preparation are included in the property cost. The section expires after December 31, 2011. The tax code amendment offers a 20% credit on eligible building products and home furnishings for resale, with a maximum of $500 for joint filers ($250 for others). The credit is income-restricted and applies to environmentally compliant products. Labor expenses for onsite preparation are part of the property cost. This section is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. The tax code provides a 10% credit on qualified building products and home furnishings purchased for resale, with a maximum credit of $10,000 per year. The definition of qualified products includes items used in personal residences. Control groups are considered as a single employer for this credit. The tax code allows a 10% credit on building products and home furnishings for resale, with a maximum credit of $10,000 per year. Control groups are treated as a single taxpayer for this credit, and special rules apply for allocation. The tax code allows a 10% credit on building products and home furnishings for resale, with a maximum credit of $10,000 per year. Special rules apply for allocation, and the credit determined under section 45R is subject to separate application and limitations. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2008.
